intro: Leucocarpum, commonly known as the ghost flower, is a genus of flowering plants native to the southern hemisphere. It belongs to the family Myrtaceae and is characterized by its unique, white, waxy flowers that resemble ghostly shapes. The plants typically grow in moist, shaded environments, such as rainforests or swampy areas. Leucocarpum species are often epiphytic, meaning they grow on the surfaces of other plants without parasitizing them. Their botanical significance lies in their unusual morphology and ecological adaptations.
